activities: While IDT911 does not currently receive any data transfers from any organizations in E.U. member states, IDT911 is expanding into the E.U. and is employing E.U.  data subjects. It is possible that limited HR data may be passed between the E.U. and U.S. between IDT911’s different operations. In addition, as IDT911 expands and builds out services, situations may require  transfer of limited personal private data by a European Data Subject by Q3 2015. In order to ensure industry best practices, IDT911 wishes to follow E.U./U.S. Safe Harbor Framework requirements in the chance that we must work with an E.U. citizen.requirements in the chance that we must work with an E.U. citizen.
eucountries: Austria, Belgium, Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, United Kingdom
personaldata: Data includes any information on a EU citizen who ALSO has a U.S. issued Social Security Number due to them having a valid work visa, gren card, or dual citizenship in the U.S. and their home country. Data is limited to data provided by the data subject to us for use to resolve U.S related identity fraud.
recoursemech: BBB EU (Better Business Bureau) SAFE HARBOR PRIVACY DISPUTE RESOLUTION Program Participation
